g.text: It should be noted that the protocol described above fails for grains accidentally oriented with domain normal

cannot be well determined. However, the expression for the surface normal
is still reasonably estimated by this
method. For determination of the in-plane orientation of such grain, that is for the

if a high precision in crystal grain orientation is needed, one can always abandon equation (
direct numerical fitting of the measured
profiles to the exact expressions given by equations (
Finally, we would like to stress that the form of the Raman tensor given in equation (
degenerate Raman mode in any of the five cubic point groups. Therefore, the present method and the equations
) are valid for all cubic crystals having a first-order Raman active mode transforming as a two-dimensional
symmetry). In particular, it applies to both centrosymmetric and
noncentrosymmetric cubic crystal structures. Obviously, the simplest cubic structures like rock-salt or cubic
perovskite have no Raman active modes at all. On the other hand, a similar approach can be adopted even for
certain noncubic crystals, for example the angular dependence of the pure transverse optic mode of rhombo-
, seems to have almost identical polarization dependence with respect to the
pseudocubic axes as the cubic doublet modes investigated here
. Nevertheless, as mentioned in the introduction,
there are other, more straightforward optic and Raman scattering methods available for noncubic crystals, too.
In conclusion, we have realised that the strong polarisation dependence of Raman scattering by
metry modes in cubic materials could be used to determine crystallographic orientation of an arbitrarily oriented
crystal facet. We have derived and tested approximate analytic expressions that allow of determining both the
crystallographic orientation of the surface normal as well as the crystallographic orientation of a selected direc-
tion in the crystal surface. The method can be applied to any cubic material with
Comparison of Raman scattering and EBSD techniques applied to the same grains on a selected surface of GVS
ceramics indicates that the method is functional and reasonably precise. The method can be very useful when a
polycrystalline sample is used to determine anisotropic properties. In particular, we believe that this fully optical
method can have advantage as a relatively cheap alternative to EBSD or in a limited experimental environment,
for example when in-situ EBSD is not available but optical microscopy can be arranged.
was synthesised by direct single-step synthesis from elements. Sulphur and vanadium powders were
mixed with lumps of gallium. The mixture was heated slightly by infrared lamp to melt gallium and thereafter
ground and mixed in an agate mortar. The reaction mixture was put into the silica glass ampoule previously filled
with argon. The ampoule was evacuated by a rotary pump, filled with argon, again evacuated, filled with argon,
finally evacuated to residual argon pressure of about 2 mbar and sealed. The ampoule with reaction mixture was
slowly heated at a rate of 40 K/h to 1270 K in a chamber furnace, annealed for 7 days and cooled at 10 K/min. The
slow heating is necessary to allow the reaction of sulphur, since at quick heating the high pressure of sulphur can
burst the ampoule. Unlike the experience of other authors this single-step synthesis resulted in pure single-phase
powders as was proved by X-ray diffraction. The powder was axially pressed at a pressure of 380 MPa. The
sintering was done again in a sealed silica glass ampoule by the same annealing procedure as for the synthesis of
pellet has 99% purity according to X-ray diffraction. Samples were cut
from the sintered pellet with a diamond cut-off wheel and then mechanically polished using diamond suspen-
sions with particle sizes of 9 and 3
m. Final mechanical-chemical polishing was performed using a solution of
The electron microscopy imaging and EBSD measurements were performed at 15 kV using an FEI Quanta 3D
FEG scanning electron microscope equipped with TSL/EDAX Hikari camera. The EBSD analysis was done using
Raman scattering measurements were carried out using a Renishaw Raman microscope with 514 nm Argon
laser in back-scattering geometry and a very similar set-up as the one used in our previous systematic polarised
The datasets generated and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on

dependence of the intensity of the strongest
-symmetry Raman mode in the parallel-polarised Raman
spectrum. The crystallographic coordinates of the reference direction vector
from Raman scattering and EBSD, respectively.
